awd_titl_txt: Approaches to Diverse Fluoroorganics and Fluorinated Building Blocks
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Barbara Zajc in the Department of Chemistry at the City College of the City University of New York.  Professor Zajc and her students develop novel methods for synthesis of fluorinated organic compounds.  Organofluorine compounds are of importance in diverse fields, including agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals, materials sciences, and as biological probes.  Approximately one in five pharmaceuticals contains a fluorine atom. Fluorine-18 (18F) labeled organofluorine compounds are often used in medicine (for positron emission tomography (PET) imaging).  As an example, 2-deoxy-2-(18F)-D-glucose is commonly used in brain imaging.  Organofluorine compounds are also rapidly gaining importance as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) contrast agents - also used in the diagnosis of disease.  19F MRI is being studied for brain imaging, for instance, visualizing amyloid plaque formation in Alzheimer's disease.  Development of novel methods for the efficient synthesis of organofluorine compounds, which is the focus of this funded project, is therefore of strong interest.  Students in Professor Zajc's research group are of diverse ethnicity and from an international community.  Research projects are designed for training students at all educational levels, in order to provide experience in an area of societal relevance.

The unique and valuable properties of organofluorine compounds make them important in a range of scientific areas.  However, selective introduction of fluorine atoms into organic molecules continues to be challenging.  This project develops novel chemical approaches to various classes of regiospecifically fluorinated compounds - those containing chiral centers.  Some of the molecules developed may have a direct impact on studying neurodegenerative disorders.  The approaches undertaken here focus on modular assemblies using new fluorinated building blocks.  Where applicable, the role of fluorine on reactivity is studied.  Due to the widespread importance of organofluorine compounds in medicinal and biological chemistry, including diagnostics such as the study of brain disorders using 19F MRI imaging, this research may have impact in areas beyond chemical synthesis.  The research activities involve education and training of students from diverse ethnic groups, including those that are underrepresented in the sciences.  The City College of New York has a large minority student population, and their education and training has an impact on a diversified workforce.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Fluorine is a small atom, but it is most electronegative (affinity for electrons) and forms the strongest single bond to carbon. When introduced into organic compounds, all these features contribute to its unique effect on the physical, chemical, and biological properties. Synthesis of fluorinated organic compounds is therefore of interest in plethora of fields, such as pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials, to name a few. Despite its significance and importance, selective introduction of fluorine atom into organic molecules continues to be a challenge. Our research has been involved with an approach where smaller fluorinated molecules, called building blocks, are synthesized. Subsequently, the use of these fluorinated building blocks to synthesize more complex molecules is studied. The NSF award allowed us to develop a novel approach to various chiral fluorinated building blocks, where the chirality introduction could be controlled by specific reaction conditions.  We demonstrated that these novel building blocks could be used for synthesis of unnatural fluorinated amino alcohols and amino acids. Both, amino alcohols and amino acids are widely prevalent in nature and have important biological functions. Current trends in the design of new pharmaceuticals are the inclusion of amino acid, or amino alcohol structural elements into drug candidates. According to a recent review, 40% of newly approved drugs contain an amino acid structural moiety. Similarly, incorporation of one or more fluorine atom(s) into a pharmaceutical for modulation of the activity, is another growing trend. Approximately 20% of drugs marketed in recent years contain a fluorine atom. The methods that we developed allow access to more complex chiral molecules that contain either an amino alcohol or amino acid structural element and a fluorine atom. We also expanded the use of these fluorinated building blocks to the synthesis of fluorovinyl amino alcohols and amino acids, by the Julia-Kocienski olefination approach. This is our newest addition to the expanding fluoroolefination toolbox that we have developed through prior NSF awards. Nucleosides are another class of biomolecules that are present in all living beings. Novel approaches for their modification have potential wide-ranging applications in biochemistry and medicine, such as providing access to novel compounds with potential antiviral or anticancer properties. The current NSF award also allowed us to develop a new synthetic approach to modified nucleosides and deoxynucleosides. For this, we developed a straightforward, scalable, and facile synthesis of nucleoside building blocks, which were used for further derivatization.  Via these nucleoside building blocks, we introduced a variety of substituents, such as enonyl and fluoroenonyl groups. In our studies we also used molecular modeling to better understand results obtained in the chemical methods developed.

Students at The City College of New York (CCNY) are of diverse ethnicities and come from diverse backgrounds. Many are under-represented in the STEM field. NSF funding enabled them to participate in contemporary research and to gain state-of-the-art skills, critical for success in their future careers.  In this context, the PI?s research group has typically involved students of all educational levels, i.e., undergraduate, masters, doctoral students, and postdoctoral associates. Through the years, PI?s research program not only attracted a number of minority students, but also a large number of females. Many have received CCNY and/or national awards and have gone on to pursue successful careers, ranging from academic to private sector.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Barbara Zajc
